html:
Nov 17 (Reuters) - The following are the top stories on the business pages of British newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.


The Times


The government has ordered an in-depth investigation into the planned $54 billion takeover of Arm, the British microchip designer, over competition and national security concerns, in the latest regulatory obstacle to the deal. https://bit.ly/3kLBVNw


The Guardian


Premier Foods' PFD.L Mr Kipling is heading to the United States in January with chocolate and salted caramel cakes after a successful trial in Canada. https://bit.ly/30ufPIa


Sainsbury's SBRY.L has teamed up with Amazon AMZN.O to test a "just walk out" store, where it is possible to buy groceries without having to scan items or visit a till. https://bit.ly/3nmicpz


The Telegraph


The gas-rich Gulf state of Qatar is poised to invest up to £100m in Rolls-Royce's RR.L plan to develop a new generation of mini nuclear reactors that are far cheaper and faster to build than traditional designs. https://bit.ly/3kEad5t


Vodafone VOD.L is gearing up for a European merger spree after a jump in smartphone sales helped the mobile company boost its profits and soothed fears over its troubled German arm. https://bit.ly/3Frkzh5



Sky News


The chairman of the Premier League is on the brink of resigning following a backlash from clubs over its handling of the Saudi-led takeover of Newcastle United. https://bit.ly/3oGPKOK


Two more UK energy firms have collapsed - as a pipeline delay in Europe further added to the wholesale price pressures that have created a crisis in the industry. https://bit.ly/3kJ8DPJ



The Independent


A proposed oil field in Scottish waters "should not get the green light", the first minister, Nicola Sturgeon has said. https://bit.ly/3qNQrIv




(Compiled by Bengaluru newsroom)

(( globalnewsmonitoring@thomsonreuters.com ))

Keywords: BRITAIN-PRESS/BUSINESS
